ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about a broad range of syntactic theory and how it evolved over time

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There can be some difficulties for students who don't speak languages besides English. Some of the assignments are framed with the expectation that you know about a non-English language well enough to identify syntactically interesting phenomena in it. This can add an extra barrier to some assignments if you don't speak another language.

Strengths: teaching and knowledge of material, in-class activities in breakout rooms, combination of lecturing and student-led discussions, problem sets infrequent but covered appropriate material and challenged us as well, adjusting to student needs and slowing down for review weeks 
Weaknesses: pace of course rapid at times (although great deal of information to cover), which led to difficulties grasping intricacies; pandemic and outside circumstances made all types of learning (including this course) more difficult

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Success: breakout rooms, both professor and student discussions, recorded lectures, resources available to learn from
Improved: class too early in the morning for some, cold-calling was anxiety-creating during midterms season, would be helpful to include a summary sheet of all the theories and concepts around midterms (or to start a class document) because it was hard to keep track of everything after a certain point

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a really great course, and well taught.
Yes! Especially for those who wish to delve into syntax more deeply after Syntax I

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Discussion board posts were also featured.
Virtual seminar with slides and readings ahead of times and some flipped classroom work with in-class activities and sharing knowledge with classmates
